_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Arctic Cold Storage                             6/17/04
                                                              4360 S Haggerty
                                                              Canton Mi. 48188

       Arctic  Cold Storage is a public refrigerated warehouse and is a member of the IARW (International
Association of Refrigerated Warehouses) and TRRF (The Refrigerated Research Fondation). Total refrigerated
space is 132972 sq. ft. totaling 3.9 million cu. Ft. Temperatures range from -20 F to +30 F with a 45 F dock
and 22 dock doors.

      Ammonia is the refrigerant used in the refrigeration system. Ammonia safety is what this summary is about.
Ammonia is an extremely hazardous substance that has been used in refrigeration since the late 1800.
When ammonia systems are designed properly, maintained properly and maintained by qualified personnel they
are extremely safe. As a good nieghbor we want to exhibit to you that Arctic Cold Storage follows the important 
guidelines.

      System design follows or exceeds codes set by the state of Michigan. We also follow guidelines set by the
IIAR. For example it is not required by code that the ventilation system can be started from a remote location 
outside the compressor room. IIAR recommends this, so we do. Emergency shutdown can also be done from off
site by computer. The entire system is monitored by computer with a repetitive callout system to plant personnel
when there is an alarm or failure. Remember that an alarm or failure does not mean a ammonia release. It only
means that a safety in tha system has worked.

      Some 100,000 ammonia refrigeration plants are operating in countries around the world. Man is producing
approximatley 120,000,000 tons of ammonia yearly for use as fertilizers and for the chemical industry etc., which
accounts for some 98% of all the ammonia used. The remainder is involved in refrigeration applications. The
ref

rigeration charge at ACS is 16,000 lbs. at 5 lbs. to the gal (lighter than air as a vapor) that?s approximatley 3200
gals. There has been no releases other than normal maintenance pumpdowns and no additional ammonia 
brought in. There have been no ammonia related accidents at ACS.

       In the event of a accidental release, that could have offsite site consequences it is the policy of ACS that
emergency shutdown takes place, calls are made to the LEPC, Fire Department and that all employees are
evacuated to emergency assembly areas. Only trained personnel will respond to the leak. Emergency shutdown
stops all compressors all pumps and all selonoid valves go to the closed position. All this can be done with one 
switch in the General Managers office. Since all compressing of ammonia gas is stopped and pumping of 
liquid ammonia is stopped a serious leak is miminized. The alternative scenario is somethig more realistic. This 
scenario would propally happen in the compressor room and would go as follows.  A seal fails on a pump or 
compressor or a worker makes a mistake while performing maintenance. There are steps to prevent these kind of 
accident. Basic preventive maintenance and training are the keys. Seals rarely fail without giving the operator 
notice, oil on the floor, the smell of ammonia that wasn't there the day before, tells the operator that steps need
to be taken. Since ammonia is detectable at levels as low as 3 to 5 parts per million small leaks can be found and
repaired before they become serious. ACS has a no leak is tolerable policy. A review of the task to be done is the
fisrt step. What drawings do we need to look at? How do we get all the ammonia out of the system that needs to 
be opened? What valves need to be closed? Is the safety equipment there if something unexpected happens?
Most ammonia releases at refrigerated warehouses happen while the system was either being added on to or 
maintenance was being done. The second most probable cause w

ould be fork lifts. At ACS the compressor room 
is locked and off limits to fork lifts. From there all ammonia piping is on the roof. The penthouse evaporators cannot 
be reached by fork lifts. Dock evaporators are over racks putting them out of the path of fork lifts. We are required 
by OSHA to to have a process management program in place and it must be followed.This is not a burden to ACS 
but a helpful tool to help us keep our equipment running, and our employees safe.

       As the chief engineer at ACS I hold a first class refrigeration operators license from the city of Detroit. I have
held this license for 25 years. It qualifies me to operate a refrigeration system of unlimited HP and unlimited lbs.
of refrigerant. I have also attended several classes at the University of Wisconsin on the design and construction
of freezers, coolers and process rooms, ammonia refrigeration system safety and classes at the manufactures
plant of our refrigeration equipment. ACS also employees a assistant engineer who is also a licensed operator.

      I would like to close this summary with a brief review of ACS. This is not a process facility where we are taking
ammonia in running it through a process, mixing it with other products to make a new product and sending it back out.
The ammonia in this plant is the same ammonia that was put in here in 1994. Using the same basic principles that
the home refrigerator uses, evaporating the liquid to a vapor cools our building, compressing the vapor and 
condensing it back to a liquid to be evaporated again, over and over the process goes day in and day out. There 
have been no accidental releases, no ammonia related injuries. We are also going to explore new mitigation devices 
that help to control a worst case scenario. We welcome visits by anyone or any organization that would like to view 
our plant.



                                                                                                       Sincerely
